entry now related to this topic RFID um I was driving around and I saw
these antennas on these Street posts and I was wondering what they were cuz they were pointing down into the lane on the road and so I got my laptop out and
captured it with my own yagi there and then it turned out to be FasTrack so this is those um re uh modules that you
put on your wind screen so that when you go through electronic toall booths I'm sure you're all familiar with it and they have different names everywhere but
the toll booth can identify you and then subtract from your account and so somehow these things contain an account
ID and they're read as you as you drive through and this is actually um one of the toll booths at the or the toll booth
at the Golden Gate Bridge and I went there with myagi and my laptop and was looking very very um well let's say not
suspicious pointing it at the T boo um but Fast Track is interesting because it uses 900 MHz ISM a wake up signal will
wake up your tag but the tag does not have a radio inside it that will actively transmit back it
uses this thing called back scanner modulation so it'll be energized and there's a a passive antenna that is
inside and the load will change on it that's controlled by a little microprocessor and the radar cross-section of that antenna will
change and the way that it changes will actually be the modulation of your data that's read back by the reader so it's a
really really clever system and they have a long lifely them battery in there and it lasts for years and you don't have to replace it cuz it's not actively
transmitting it's just changing the way it looks to the transmitter so if you were to look at the signal again it's a
similar sort of thing like the keyless entry all this stuff is linked there's a lot of really similar stuff in in all of
these different protocols so there's a wake up there's a preamble there's the payload in this case it's saying hey
tell me your ID and then because it's back scatter you need to energize the tag and so you have this unmodulated
back scatter carry that's transmit transmitted to the tag um and so what
you can do is you can use this really cool RF device called the circulator you transmit in Port one and then you hook
your antenna up to Port two and all the energy coming around from one two will go out of the antenna but it won't
continue around to Port three and any energy that ends up coming in from the antenna will come out of port three but
it won't come back around to Port one so it's this way of isolating these ports and so that way you can actually get a
usurp do transmit and receive have the circulator in there and and use a single antenna to both energize the tag and
read it as its radar cross-section changes and so what you can do then is you can hopefully the signal is familiar
to you that's the one I just showed you before that's going to be the interrogation and then you have this UNM modulated carrier when you put the tag
there in front of the antenna then it will'll suddenly have this back scatter uh energy received and then modulated on
top of this back scatter carrier and that's what actually contains in this case my fast trck ID and so none of this
is is encrypted so I could just hold it up and and it'll read it um and g r flow
graph will look for the the Preamble coming back from the tag using a match filter and then sample the bits and then
decode the data so behind the windshield hold the anten
up to it and then read so you can go around and read everyone's tag and of course they
implications of that you can spoof people or stand on a bridge above a highway and or you know track people and
so on uh and this is is the flow graph for that one it's a little bit more complicated but it comes down to this um
fast TR decoder block that knows how to decode this particular protocol um and in a similar vein with back scatter this
is the you know of course you know I imagine most of you have key fobs at the
office to get through doors security badges this is the um recorded um
transaction there and you can see here that again it's sort of split up into these stages of wake up and and Preamble
and some sort of challenge response if you look into this um uh large bit of
data here then this is using back scatter because you know with these RFID tags they're passive so the reader will
energize it the microprocessor will start running and do some computation and send back the result and you can tell what's going on here because with
these larger bits of energy on this back scatter carrier the larger bit of energy is the reader sending out its Challenge
and then the small bit that comes back is the back scatter response from your tag and so you can see how the
transaction happens there so I didn't really pursue this any further it was just more about seeing how you could apply this to to do some reading and
then if you wanted to do your own analysis you could continue on from there um so that's that's that sort of
